analytic.title: THE SOCIAL IOWA GAMBLING TASK (S-IGT)

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The unique distinctions between non-social and social learning and decision making are largely unknown. Facial cues, critical in forming first impressions of trustworthiness, may influence maladaptive social learning, such as prioritizing appearances over actions and settling for satisfactory outcomes. To test this, we augmented a well-established measure of learning and decision making, the Iowa Gambling Task, to examine the role of social (face) cues in learning. Our newly developed Social Iowa Gambling Task (S-IGT) includes: 1) the experimental manipulation of facial cues of trustworthiness; 2) the incorporation of two conditions in which the dis/advantageous decks are represented by un/trustworthy faces (i.e., congruent condition; CS-IGT) and vice versa (i.e., incongruent condition; IS-IGT); and (3) a nonsocial control condition. With these features, the new S-IGT goes beyond widely used multiround trust games and expands on their ability to model the influence of social context during decision making. Across three studies, 558 participants were randomly assigned to complete either the IGT or one of the two conditions of the S-IGT (i.e., in/congruent). Participants showed the best initial performance in the CS-IGT, but also evidenced the least improvement over time in this condition and most disadvantageous decision making after learning (i.e., during the last block). Results from this novel task support the notion that congruence between facial cues of trustworthiness and behavior can inhibit learning and result in inadequate/suboptimal decision making, perhaps because they promote satisficing.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Adaptive social decision making requires the ability to accurately distinguish "cooperators" from "cheaters" (Cosmides & Tooby, 1989;Suzuki et al., 2019). This distinction has been investigated in laboratory settings using behavioral economic approaches, most commonly through paradigms such as the Trust Game and the Ultimatum Game (Von Neumann & Morgenstern, 1947). These paradigms help elucidate how decisions are shaped by a context's "social frame", reflecting expectations of fairness and reciprocity (Blount, 1995;Frazier et al., 2021).

While traditional versions of economic decision games are widely used, variations of these tasks and alternative paradigms have been proposed to capture the nuances of complex social choice (Rilling & Sanfey, 2011). Because making decisions in the real world is dependent on multiple interactions with social partners, researchers have increasingly utilized multi-round economic games rather than "one-shot" designs. Multi-round games demonstrate that behavior and judgements evolve with ongoing partner interactions, offering a robust framework for observing the evolution of trust and decision-making strategies over time (Axelrod & Hamilton, 1981;Rilling & Sanfey, 2011). Implicit learning plays a significant role in how we navigate and interpret our social world. This form of learning, particularly relevant when considering the influence of external factors such as facial features, as opposed to explicit behavior, is crucial in understanding the unspoken, often unconscious, elements of social exchange. Studies have shown that nonverbal cues like facial expressions and body language can greatly influence trust decisions in repeated interactions, albeit their exact impact is not fully understood yet (Eckel & Wilson, 2003;Morris et al., 1998;Willis & Todorov, 2006). This brings to light the concept of schemas-mental frameworks shaped by past experiences (i.e., based on "schemata"; Bartlett, 1932)-and how they can lead to biases in information processing and decision making (Ebner et al., 2009;Lempert et al., 2022;Mather & Johnson, 2003;Owens et al., 1979).

The literature points to an intriguing pattern: congruent facial cues, whether emotional or non-emotional, tend to amplify trust or distrust judgments based on the outcomes of interactions (Campellone & Kring, 2013;Chang et al., 2010). This pattern indicates that consistent facial cues and interaction outcomes lead to more optimal investment patterns, while incongruent cues initially impact decisions but are overridden by repeated, conflicting outcomes. However, it remains unclear how facial cues of trustworthiness impact behavior in contexts where social interaction outcomes involve both costs and benefits (e.g., gains/losses) and when the likelihood of reciprocity is more difficult to remember explicitly. One possibility is that congruent facial cues lead to more optimal decision making over time, and incongruent facial cues lead to initial biases (e.g., favoring trustworthy-looking partners) that are increasingly ignored as participants with conflicting interaction outcomes have an expectation for reciprocity.
Expanding on these insights, our study delves into the intricacies of "satisficing" behavior in social decision making, particularly when explicit memory of interactions is challenged.

Satisficing, refers to a decision-making strategy that aims for a satisfactory or adequate result, rather than the optimal solution (Gigerenzer & Todd, 1999). This concept is particularly relevant in complex social interactions, where weighing every possible outcome is impractical.

Individuals employing satisficing will accept choices that meet minimum requirements, thereby reducing the cognitive effort involved in decision making. In the context of our study, we explore how this behavior manifests in social decision making, especially when individuals are faced with facial cues that either align or conflict with their expectations or past experiences. The novel Social Iowa Gambling Task (S-IGT), introduced in this paper, allows for differentiation between these cognitive processes, advancing understanding of decision making in social contexts.

div.head: Social Iowa Gambling Task (S-IGT)
div.p: To assess the influence of facial cues on social learning and decision making, we developed the Social Iowa Gambling Task (S-IGT), an adaptation of the well-established Iowa Gambling Task (IGT; Bechara et al., 1994). In this novel social variant of the IGT, participants are presented with social (face) stimuli, wherein the trustworthiness of these facial cues is experimentally manipulated to examine its impact on decision making. The S-IGT comprises two distinct conditions: (1) congruent (CS-IGT): trustworthy-and untrustworthy-looking facial cues align with advantageous and disadvantageous decks, respectively; and (2) incongruent (IS-IGT): trustworthy-and untrustworthy-looking facial cues are associated with disadvantageous and advantageous decks, respectively. In addition to the two social conditions, a non-social control condition using the standard IGT without facial stimuli was used here to establish a baseline for comparison.

The standard IGT was originally developed to measure integrative emotional-cognitive decision making, specifically exploring the somatic marker hypothesis in individuals with prefrontal neurological damage. This hypothesis states that as decision-making complexity increases, emotions and feelings become essential decision signals (Denburg & Hedgcock, 2015). These emotions and feelings, theorized as "somatic markers," are then integrated into the process through the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (Bechara et al., 2005).

Our adaptation of the IGT to examine social learning and decision making served several purposes. While trust learning studies traditionally utilize neuroeconomic tasks such as the Trust Game, Prisoner's Dilemma, or Ultimatum Game (Rilling & Sanfey, 2011), the S-IGT uniquely captures the complexity and reliance on non-declarative memory present in real-world social learning across multiple interactions. Furthermore, the IGT's well-established ecological validity has been used to investigate decision making in various populations with social decision-making impairments (Bauer et al., 2013;Bechara et al., 1994;Maurage et al., 2018;Rupp et al., 2016). The psychometric properties of the IGT have allowed researchers to not only probe emotional learning and decision-making processes (i.e., somatic marker hypothesis; Denburg & Hedgcock, 2015), but also to examine learning and decision making under conditions of uncertainty (i.e., analyzing performance in the first 40 trials during contingency learning; Bechara & Martin, 2004;Brand et al., 2006;Maurage et al., 2018) and conditions of experience (i.e., analyzing performance in the last block, after contingencies are presumably learned).

Previous work has successfully adapted the IGT to study learning and decision making in individuals with anxiety disorders by representing the IGT choice options with pictures of spiders/butterflies as well as pictures of angry/happy faces (Pittig et al., 2014(Pittig et al., , 2015. Our newlydeveloped S-IGT: 1) uses facial stimuli with neutral emotional expressions and subtle cues of un/trustworthiness that are less likely to trigger experimenter demand effects, 2) the inclusion of a task condition in which advantageous decks are paired with non-aversive stimuli to examine the impact of congruent trustworthy-advantageous stimuli on social decisions to trust, and 3) the inclusion of, and thus direct comparison with, a standard, non-social condition of the IGT to determine whether visual social cues generally impact learning. Thus, our S-IGT represents a novel paradigm to study social learning and decision making that provides important comparison conditions that give a better accounting of social influences on learning and decision making; and its social stimuli allow for isolating effects of facial cues of trustworthiness.

div.head: Purpose of the Current Study
div.p: To summarize, here we used the S-IGT to test competing hypotheses about congruence and incongruence of social facial cues with advantageous and disadvantageous choice options.

We expected increased satisficing to occur when participants were presented with schemacongruent stimuli versus when they were presented with schema-incongruent information over multiple interactions. This study allowed us to test the extent to which social cues affect decisions to dis/trust in an implicit trust paradigm incorporating real-world features of repeated interactions and interactions that yield a mixture of costs and benefits.

We predicted that participants would perform better over the course of the task in the congruent-social (CS-IGT) than in the incongruent-social (IS-IGT) condition, while worst in the (non-social) IGT. This directional prediction was based on the notion that facial cues of trustworthiness would be a large factor in participants' card selection strategy, aiding in the congruent and hindering in the incongruent condition; while the relative lack of information in the IGT therefore may result in relatively worse performance overall than in any of the social conditions. Also, previous research on using a variant of the IGT (i.e., the Spider Gambling Task; Pittig et al., 2014) partially support differential predictions for the congruent-social vs.

incongruent-social conditions, in that spider-fearful participants performed better in the nonconflict (i.e., when the advantageous decks were represented by butterflies) than in the conflict (i.e., when the advantageous decks were represented by spiders) condition.

div.head: Method
div.p: This study tested the unique distinctions between social and non-social learning and decision making, with a particular focus on the role of facial cues in shaping social decisions. In particular, we investigated the extent to which reliance on facial cues of trustworthiness influenced adaptive and maladaptive social learning.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Data and materials for this study are available in the Open Science Framework (https://osf.io/socialigt). The Institutional Review Board at the University of Florida approved the study protocol, all participants provided written informed consent. Participants were recruited from the university undergraduate psychology participant pool (SONA), fliers posted in the community, and word-of-mouth. Phone screenings were conducted to confirm participants were aged 18-35 years and English speaking. A total of 558 participants were randomly assigned to one of three task conditions: non-social (IGT), congruent-social (CS-IGT), or incongruent-social (IS-IGT; see Table 1 for sample descriptive statistics). See the Supplemental Materials for results from a sensitivity analysis for sample size justification.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Data for this analysis were harmonized across three data collections: The first two were conducted in an in-person setting lasting approximately 60 minutes, with participants receiving monetary compensation (plus a task bonus) and the tasks using images of middle-aged male faces. The third was an online data collection using the Pavlovia platform, with participants receiving SONA credits (no task bonus) and the tasks using images of middle-aged female faces (see Supplement Materials for details) 1 .

After written informed consent, participants completed a short demographics questionnaire, followed by their assigned task condition (see details below) and socioemotional questionnaires (data not presented here). The session closed with participant debriefing and compensation.

div.head: Standard and Social Iowa Gambling Task Conditions
div.p: To mitigate potential practice effects observed in previous IGT studies (Bauer et al., 2013;Halfmann et al., 2014;Xiao et al., 2013), we adopted a between-subjects design, with each participant assigned to only one of the three task conditions (IGT, CS-IGT, or IS-IGT).

div.head: IGT
div.p: The task was programmed in PsychoPy (v3.0.6; Peirce et al., 2019). In all conditions, participants were given 2,000 points to begin the task and were instructed to make selections from four decks. Each deck of cards was represented by standard Bicycle brand card backs.

Consistent with the literature, participants were not aware of the number of times they could draw from the decks or the payout amounts. Participants were told that every draw from a deck would yield some points, but some draws would result in a penalty. Unbeknownst to them, two of the decks were designed to be "disadvantageous" (i.e., resulted in a net loss of 250 points over 10 selections) and the other two to be "advantageous" (i.e., resulted in a net gain of 250 points over 10 selections). That is, cards drawn from disadvantageous decks could result in large rewards but could also result in large punishments. Cards selected from advantageous decks, in contrast, could result in small rewards but could also result in small punishments.

As shown in Figure 1, during the task, participants were presented with their current and their previous turn's total points at the top of the computer screen as well as the total number of points they accumulated up to that point in the task. As in the original IGT, both disadvantageous card decks were always located on the left side of the screen and both advantageous card decks always on the right side of the screen (Bechara et al., 1994). All three task conditions followed the reinforcement schedule reported in Bechara et al. (see Table 1S in the Supplemental Materials for details).

div.head: CS-IGT and IS-IGT
div.p: In the S-IGT conditions, the instructions from the IGT were modified to frame the task in a social context (see the Supplemental Materials for complete instructions for all three task conditions). The S-IGT paired faces with each deck and participants were told that previous study participants built the four decks with which they were to play. The face images used to represent each social deck were taken from the FACES database (Ebner et al., 2010). We used faces of middle-aged adults to avoid own-age biases (Rhodes & Anastasi, 2012;Slessor et al., 2014). Also, as race effects were not targeted in this study, race-associated facial features were not manipulated. All facial expressions were neutral (non-emotional). The four selected face images were the two most and the two least trustworthy-looking faces based on trustworthiness ratings on a scale from 0 (i.e., not trustworthy at all) to 100 (i.e., very trustworthy) obtained from participants in an independent study (Pehlivanoglu et al., 2023). See Table 2S in Supplemental Materials for descriptive statistics of the trustworthiness ratings of the face stimuli. In the congruent-social condition (CS-IGT), advantageous decks were paired with the two most trustworthy faces and disadvantageous decks with the two least trustworthy faces. In the incongruent-social condition (IS-IGT), this pairing was reversed. We administered two versions of the CS-IGT and two versions of the IS-IGT that switched the face-deck associations within advantageous and disadvantageous decks. For example, in Version 1 of the congruent condition Face 1 was paired with Deck C and Face 2 was paired with Deck D and in version 2 the faces switched between the two decks. The same was true for the incongruent condition, resulting in five possible conditions -IGT, CS-IGT1, CSIGT2, IS-IGT1, and IS-IGT2.
Assignment to these conditions was counterbalanced.

div.head: Statistical Analyses
div.p: First, to determine if participants were more likely to make their initial selection from a deck represented by a trustworthy compared to an untrustworthy face, a single sample Chi-Square analysis on participants' first selection was conducted for the S-IGT conditions. Our main analyses examined task performance by 20-trial blocks. Consistent with prior studies (Bauer et al., 2013;Halfmann et al., 2014;Xiao et al., 2013), task performance was determined per block by calculating the total number of draws from advantageous decks minus the total number of draws from disadvantageous decks.

Given the hierarchical data structure (trials nested within participants), we used (four 20-trial blocks) as a within-subject independent variable. This analysis allowed us to test for a significant two-way interaction between these two factors and to then decompose the predicted interaction using Bonferroni correction for pairwise comparisons. Note, as in the original experiment (Bechara et al., 1994), decks included only 40 non-replenishing cards, similar to playing the game with physical playing cards. 1

div.head: Initial Deck Selection
div.p: Consistent with findings from other social decision-making paradigms using facial stimuli (Castle et al., 2012;Chang et al., 2010;Todorov et al., 2009;van 't Wout & Sanfey, 2008;Winston et al., 2002), the single sample Chi-Square for first deck selection in the two S-IGT conditions was significant χ 2 (1, 380) = 169.78, p < .001. First selections were more likely to be from a deck represented by a trustworthy compared to a non-trustworthy face (317 vs. 63 choices, respectively). Thus, as expected, facial trustworthiness cues biased initial decision making (toward trustworthy-looking/away from untrustworthy-looking faces) in the absence of additional information about choice outcomes.

div.head: Choice Performance Over Time
div.p: The Task Condition x Block interaction was significant, Wald χ 2 (6) = 24.84, p = .0004. Decomposition of this significant two-way interaction showed that performance over the course of the task was better in the IGT than the CS-IGT, Wald χ 2 (3) = 10.95, p = .01, as well as the IGT than the IS-IGT, Wald χ2(3) = 9.65, p = .02; and performance was better in the CS-IGT than the IS-IGT, Wald χ 2 (3) = 14.87, p = .002. As expected, performance in Block 1 was the lowest in the IS-IGT relative to both the CS-IGT (z = -7.57, p < .001) and the IGT (z = -4.76, p < .001), with comparable performance between the CS-IGT and the IGT (z = 1.47, p = 1.00). By Block 4, however, participants in the IGT outperformed those in the IS-IGT (z = 3.98, p = .001), while performance in the CS-IGT did not significantly differ from that in the IGT (z = -2.15, p = .254) nor the IS-IGT (z = 2.38, p = .14). That is, participants improved the least in the CS-IGT and the most in the IGT and the IS-IGTwith the latter two task conditions showing overall similar trajectories of improvement by block. Figure 2 summarizes these task condition effects, which illustrate the impact of facial cues of trustworthiness on initial choice selections as well as subsequent learning trajectories.

Notably, participants in the CS-IGT initially benefited from facial cues of trustworthiness, as they made somewhat more advantageous than disadvantageous choices early in the task. However, individuals in this condition showed less improvements in their performance with experience than individuals in either of the other two conditions (IS-IGT and IGT). In contrast, participants in the IS-IGT were initially more hindered by facial cues of trustworthiness but exhibited steep learning trajectories after the initial blocks. Unexpectedly, participants in the IGT, with neither congruent nor incongruent facial cues of trustworthiness, evidenced greater learning than participants in the CS-IGT and the IS-IGT

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The current study introduces a novel paradigm, the Social Iowa Gambling Task (S-IGT), designed to systematically investigate domain general (non-social) and trust (social) learning and to examine decision making under contexts of in/congruent trustworthy appearance and behavior. Our findings reveal significant differences in initial choice performance across task conditions, aligning with predictions regarding learning and decisionmaking disparities in non-social and social contexts. Namely, the pairing of trustworthiness social cues from faces with advantageous decks led to better initial performance, suggesting schema effects due to intrinsic biases. However, participants displayed the least improvement over the course of the task in the CS-IGT relative to the IGT and the IS-IGT. Furthermore, exploratory analyses revealed that participants in the CS-IGT did not demonstrate a significant learning advantage over those in the standard (non-social) IGT.

Our findings support the conclusion that the presence of incongruent facial cues of trustworthiness impaired initial choice options during the first block of the task. More specifically, our results suggest that when the initial valence of the facial cues was generally consistent with the expected values of the choice options, participants may have deferred to facial cues and directed less cognitive resources to processing choice outcomes (i.e., satisficing). Additionally, schema reliance on social facial cues in both the CS-IGT and the IS-IGT impaired learning overall when compared to the IGT.

div.head: Satisficing Behavior in the CS-IGT
div.p: Results of the present study indicated that the CS-IGT was the only task condition in which participants, on average, performed better in the first block (i.e., more advantageous choices) than in the following blocks. This initial performance difference appeared to be due to a reliance on facial cues to make initial decisions on who to trust. This finding is consistent with a wealth of evidence that facial trustworthiness affects social decisions (Castle et al., 2012;Chang et al., 2010;Todorov et al., 2009;van 't Wout & Sanfey, 2008;Winston et al., 2002) and generally supports the notion of schema reliance (Ebner et al., 2009;Lempert et al., 2022;Mather & Johnson, 2003). Choosing a trustworthy-looking face in the congruent condition of the S-IGT always resulted in profits and little to no losses since the trustworthy face was paired with an advantageous deck. This provided motivation for participants to choose a trustworthy face over an untrustworthy face in this condition.

Our results showed that participants in the CS-IGT appeared to more frequently select cards from the advantageous decks (paired with trustworthy faces) and occasionallybut not frequentlyexplored disadvantageous decks (paired with untrustworthy faces). This strategy is consistent with the phenomenon of satisficing (Gigerenzer & Todd, 1999), which requires fewer cognitive resources than integrating choice outcomes over trials and uses evolving estimates of choice values to make decisions. In our context, satisficing would mean participants rely on trustworthy faces as a quick heuristic to guide their choices, thereby conserving cognitive resources that would otherwise be expended in meticulously analyzing the outcomes associated with each deck over multiple trials.

However, the presence of this satisficing behavior does not entirely preclude other decision-making dynamics. An alternative hypothesis we must consider is that the congruence of trustworthy faces with advantageous decks could disrupt the learning process. This disruption could occur if participants, influenced by their initial strong associations with trustworthy faces, do not encode feedback from their choices as effectively, or if they experiment less, believing the congruent cues to be reliable indicators of positive outcomes. Such a mechanism could explain why, despite initially favoring decks associated with trustworthy faces, participants in the congruent condition displayed a slower adjustment in their strategies over time. This is evident in our data showing that participants did engage with disadvantageous decks, albeit at a reduced rate compared to other conditions. The slower rate of strategy adjustment in the CS-IGT suggests that while participants start with a satisficing approach, relying on the heuristic of trustworthy faces, they gradually begin to integrate feedback from their choices, although less efficiently than in conditions without such congruent cues.

The observed pattern of behavior in our study is similar to that of Pittig et al. (2014)'s adaptation of the IGT, where participants faced with pictures of butterflies on advantageous decks and pictures of spiders on disadvantageous decks ("no-conflict" condition) were the only group to exhibit advantageous performance in the first block but did not show significant improvement over the rest of the task. While our study parallels Pittig et al. (2014) in terms of initial advantageous performance in the no-conflict condition, a notable divergence arises in the progression of task performance. Unlike in Pittig et al., our study introduces an essential comparison with the no-cue condition (the standard IGT). This comparison provides valuable insights into the decision-making process. Specifically, it highlights that in the absence of any visual cues, as in the standard IGT, participants' choices are guided by different dynamics compared to when they are influenced by incongruent visual cues. The initial influence of incongruent visual cues in our task, and the subsequent need for considerable experience to override these initial biases, contrasts with the more stable performance observed in the no-cue IGT condition. This difference underscores the significant impact of visual cues on initial decision making and the learning curve required to adjust in complex decision-making environments.

Divergence between our findings and other work may also be attributable to the nature of the stimuli and task complexity used. For example, the Trust Game in Chang et al.'s (2010) study, involving simpler sequential interactions and outcomes, may have facilitated learning processes differently than our more complex IGT environment with multiple choices and mixed gains and losses. This could explain why congruent facial cues had a more pronounced effect in our study compared to Chang et al.

While there is an overlap between positive/negative valence and trustworthiness cues, they are not entirely synonymous. Trustworthiness cues, in our study, appear to have played a distinct role in the decision-making, especially in how individuals adapted their strategies over time. Therefore, our findings contribute a unique perspective to the understanding of trustworthiness in social decision making, distinct from the broader framework of positive/negative valence. They highlight the complex relationship between initial impressions based on trustworthiness and the evolution of decision-making strategies, underscoring the need for further research to disentangle these effects and explore their implications in social cognition.

Individual differences among participants and variations in experimental design could have further contributed to differences in results. Given the established construct validity of the IGT among clinical populations with decision-making impairments (Buelow & Suhr, 2009), we suggest that in certain contexts (e.g., among individuals with autism spectrum disorders or frontal lobe damage), congruent facial cues of trustworthiness trigger satisficing during the evaluation and integration of social interaction outcomes. Future research is needed to more directly examine boundary conditions that determine when congruent visual social cues benefit vs. impair learning about social partners over time.

div.head: The S-IGT As a Novel Paradigm to Study Social Learning and Decision Making
div.p: This study introduces the S-IGT as a means of measuring differences in social learning and decision making. Our findings align with previous evidence of differences in social (i.e., trust) vs. non-social (i.e., domain general) learning (Baumgartner et al., 2008;Frazier et al., 2021;Stanley, 2016), providing further evidence of a distinction between social-cognitive processes and general cognition. In this context, the S-IGT could be adopted for administration as an fMRI and/or ERP paradigm (Halfmann et al., 2014) with the aim to systematically disentangling neural signals of non-social and social learning/decision making. The task furthermore lends itself for application in diverse populations for whom social decision-making processes are currently understudied (e.g., individuals with alcohol use disorder or posttraumatic stress disorder; Le Berre et al., 2017;Saraiya et al., 2019).

div.head: Limitations and Future Research Directions
div.p: This study broadens our understanding of the intricacies involved in decision making across varied contexts, extending beyond the non-social sphere and into the domain of complex social interactions. It positions the S-IGT as an instrumental tool for delving into the multifaceted nature of social cognition, including trust. It also invites a more comprehensive exploration into a myriad of cognitive and emotional factors that influence how we engage with and interpret social cues. However, the design of the current study comes with certain limitations that offer fertile ground for future inquiry.

While the IGT is a widely used task, some studies have challenged the original theories on the implicit psychological processes involved in the task (Brevers et al., 2013;Dunn et al., 2006;Schiebener et al., 2011). This traditional view has since been replaced by new ideas on IGT performance suggesting the involvement of more emotional processes. Future studies using the S-IGT should examine additional factors influencing decision making. For example, using pictures of people from diverse backgrounds would provide a more representative capture of real-world trust interactions people encounter in their everyday life.

Our study used facial stimuli of middle-aged adults. The purpose of selecting these specific face stimuli was to avoid potential age biases in judgments of trustworthiness (Rhodes & Anastasi, 2012;Slessor et al., 2014). However, this necessarily means that none of our faces were matched to the participants' ages. It is unknown how this may have affected initial judgements of trustworthiness and/or trust-learning rates. Building on this, there is a significant opportunity for future research to systematically investigate how various dimensions of facial features, including age matching, could influence trust learning and decision-making processes.

Finally, one aspect to consider in our findings is the possibility that participants may have perceived the faces not merely as elements within the task but also as cues from the experimenter. In the S-IGT, participants' initial preference for decks with trustworthy faces could be interpreted as a response to perceived experimenter cues, suggesting 'correct' choices. Over time, especially in the CS-IGT, participants may have questioned and adjusted this strategy, as these cues did not consistently indicate deck quality. This potential interpretation of experimenter-driven cues, aligning with concepts of schema reliance and satisficing, adds a significant layer of complexity to our results and underscores the importance of considering participant perceptions in experimental design and analysis moving forward.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The present study introduces the S-IGT as a new paradigm for investigating unique distinctions between non-social (i.e., domain general) and social (e.g., trust) learning and decision making. Our findings suggest that congruence between a social partner's appearance and behavior initially leads to more accurate impressions (perhaps due to schema reliance), but ultimately triggers satisficing with negative effects on learning and performance with experience.

Participants performed better overall in the IGT, suggesting that social cues do not aid in IGT performance. It may be the case that relying on social schemas increases the demand on mental load and impairs performance when having to make decisions about social interactions.

Interestingly, participants in the CS-IGT, despite initially benefiting from congruent trustworthy cues, demonstrated less improvement with experience compared to those in the other conditions. Conversely, those in the IS-IGT, initially hindered by incongruent cues, exhibited significant learning over time. This divergence in learning trajectories highlights the complex role of trustworthiness cues in decision making, suggesting that their influence extends beyond initial impressions and requires adaptive cognitive strategies over time.

Moving forward, investigations will need to test the replicability of these findings and may utilize advanced computational modeling with neuroimaging data to determine distinguishing neurocognitive processes between non-social and social learning and decision making (e.g., neural networks subserving social cognition). The S-IGT can also be launched into clinical populations with potential deficits in trust-related learning and social decision making such as Parkinson's disease (Javor et al., 2015) in addition to studies in healthy aging (Horta et al., 2023) to more precisely identify the mechanisms underlying learning and decision making in these populations. Note. Education was measured by total years of formal education.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Graphical depiction of the standard version of the task (IGT) Note. In the social versions of the task (S-IGT), the decks of cards were represented by face images. Previous and current totals were presented above the decks on the computer screen during the task. Participants clicked on a deck to make their selection.

Results (gains and losses) of a participant's most recent selection were presented below the selected deck and previous and current totals were updated above the card decks. Participants pressed continue to progress to the next trial.

figure.figDesc: multilevel modeling (MLM) in Stata 15.1 (StataCorp. 2017. Stata Statistical Software: Release 15. College Station, TX: StataCorp LLC). The outcome variable was task performance with Task Condition (IGT, CS-IGT, IS-IGT) as a between-subject independent variable and Block

figure.head: Table 2
figure.figDesc: presents descriptive task performance (advantageousdisadvantageous choices) by Task Condition and Block. Table 3 summarizes the mean number of deck selections from each deck by Task Condition and Block 2 .

figure.head: Table 2
figure.figDesc: TaskPerformance: Means (Standard Deviations) [95% Confidence Intervals] Note. A block comprised 20 card draws. IGT = standard Iowa Gambling Task; CS-IGT = congruent Social Iowa Gambling Task; IS-IGT = incongruent Social Iowa Gambling Task.

figure.head: Table 3
figure.figDesc: Means (Standard Deviations) of Deck Selections by Block and Task Condition. Note. A block comprised 20 card draws. IGT = standard Iowa Gambling Task; CS-IGT = congruent Social Iowa Gambling Task; IS-IGT = incongruent Social Iowa Gambling Task.

body.note: Because some participants ran out of cards to choose from in Block 5, we did not include the fifth task block in our analyses (seeTable 3SandFigure 1Sin the Supplement Materials for parallel analyses including Block 5).2 The reported results represent the analysis for all harmonized data. See the SupplementalMaterials Tables 4S -6Sfor convergent results of each of the three data collections and when adding data collection as a covariate in the analyses.

analytic.title: The evolution of cooperation

monogr.title: Remembering: A study in experimental and social psychology (pp. xix, 317)

analytic.title: Myopia for the future or hypersensitivity to reward? Age-related changes in decision making on the Iowa Gambling Task

Task performance for participants in the three task conditions: IGT (solid line), congruent (CS-IGT; dotted line), and incongruent (IS-IGT

analytic.title: The x-axis indicates four blocks of 20 card draws each. The y-axis indicates the task performance operationalized as the total number of advantageous card draws minus the total number of disadvantageous card draws. Lines depict raw means and error bars of 95% confidence intervals. The significant Task Condition X Block interaction (p = .004) showed that, overall, participants in the IGT outperformed the other conditions (ps < .01), and performance was better in the CS-IGT than the IS-IGT (p = .002). Performance in Block 1 was the lowest in the IS-IGT relative to both the IGT and CS-IGT (p < .001), while performance was comparable between the CS-IGT and the IGT (p = 1.00)

monogr.title: Task performance for participants in the three task conditions: IGT (solid line), congruent (CS-IGT; dotted line), and incongruent

biblStruct.note: dashed line. by Block 4, participants in the IGT outperformed those in the IS-IGT (p < .001), and participants in the CS-IGT did not significantly differ from that in the IGT (p = .129) nor the IS-IGT (p = .244
